title: La Madrileñita

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

description:
Robert Henri dedicated his career to painting portraits of those he called “my people,” namely, sitters who evoked a personal response in the artist. He found many appealing subjects while traveling in Spain, including matadors and picadors, gypsies, dressmakers, and performers. Henri admired the subject of La Madrileñita, a 15-year-old dancer named Josefa Cruz, for her talent and traditional training, as he later recalled: “Although very young she was already a very remarkable dancer at the time the painting was done, and it seemed to me that she had in her carriage . . . much of the spirit and dignity of old Spain.” Henri painted six
portraits of Cruz; in this version, completed over the course of two days, she turns her head to look over her shoulder, directly engaging the viewer in a poised and assured manner. Her enigmatic smile bears a sense of mystery that is heightened by the darkness beyond.
publication_history: Annual report (Art Institute of Chicago, 2014–15) online only.
exhibition_history:
New York, Macbeth Galleries, 1923.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Robert Henri Memorial Exhibition, Mar–Apr. 1931; Baltimore Museum of Art, May, 1931, cat. 49.

New York, Hirschl & Adler Galleries, Robert Henri: A Commemorative Exhibition, Mar. 31–Apr. 30, 1954, cat. 33.

New York, Chapellier Galleries, Inc. Robert Henri, 1865–1929, Oct. 15–Nov. 27, 1976, cat. 49.

Orlando Museum of Art, My People: the Portraits of Ropbert Henri, Oct. 22, 1994–Jan. 8, 1995; Ft. Lauderdale Museum of Art, Feb. 5–Apr. 2, 1995; Georgia, Columbus Museum, Apr. 30–June 25, 1995, cat. 27.

Florida, Winter Park, Rollins College, Cornell Fine Arts Museum, The Independents: The Ashcan School & Their Circle from Florida Collections, Mar. 8–May 5, 1996, cat. 2.
provenance_text: The artist; to the estate of the artist, from 1929 until at least 1976 [with Chapellier Galleries, Inc., New York, from 1964]; to private collection, Winter Park, FL; sold at Christie’s New York, December 4, 1997, lot 68, to Barbara S. Danielson; bequeathed to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2014.
